p: Some of these recommendations are already being addressed by the IPCC. For example, the Special Report on 1.5C has 38% women authors, and there are now more women in leadership positions. IPCC authors are leaders in science, able to inform policy, and recognized globally as when the IPCC received the Nobel Prize for Peace in 2007. Role models are important to young aspiring scientists ( 68, 69), and women climate scientists can give voice and equal power and recognition to the half of the world that is female. Increasing the participation and voice of diverse women in the IPCC—especially those of color and from the developing world—will not only promote fairness and increase representation, but also can result in better and more influential climate science.
